info.game_comments: Battle of the Decades: The 1990s game 2.

(1, 1).clue: In 1990 his "Bourne Ultimatum" was a bestseller

(3, 1).clue: The feat of using your arms to get your chin over a bar

(4, 1).clue: This Nepalese capital's name means "wood temple" & refers to a 400-year-old temple built from a single tree

(5, 1).clue: An overnight get-together for kids in which the participants wear pajamas & stay up most of the night talking

(6, 1).clue: Kofi Annan made a deal with this Iraqi pres. to give access to weapons inspectors, & that was the end of that... right?

(1, 2).clue: Novel in which Robert Kincaid says to Francesca, "this kind of certainty comes only once"

(4, 2).clue: About one third of Latvia's people live in this capital, the largest city in the Baltic states

(5, 2).clue: This type of shindig with all-white garb was made popular by the film "Animal House"

(6, 2).clue: On Oct. 29 he returned to space as a 77-year-old payload specialist aboard the Space Shuttle

(1, 3).clue: This debut novel by Charles Frazier was a take on Homer's "Odyssey" set during the Civil War

(2, 3).clue: "Born To Boogie" &"He Could Be A Star"

(3, 3).clue: It comes before "tube" in a term of which we disapprove

(4, 3).clue: This capital's most-visited site is Ho Chi Minh's mausoleum on the edge of Ba Dinh Square

(5, 3).clue: Close off both ends of the street & turn up the music; it's time for this kind of neighborhood party

(6, 3).clue: On July 17, this ruler & some of his family members were re-buried in St. Petersburg

(1, 4).clue: In 1999 this novelist found the time to pick up a Pulitzer Prize for "The Hours"

(2, 4).clue: "But, Mr. Adams" &"The Lees Of Old Virginia"

(3, 4).clue: An island city near Montreal, or French WWII traitor Pierre

(4, 4).clue: Yaounde, capital of this former French territory in Africa, was founded by Germans involved in the ivory trade

(5, 4).clue: Guess the girth is a popular game at this type of get-together

(6, 4).clue: A site at Moton Field in Alabama was established to honor the heroic actions of this African-Amer. military group

(1, 5).clue: Roddy Doyle's bestseller about a young Irish lad growing up in the '60s is called this boy "Ha Ha Ha"

(2, 5).clue: "Hosanna" &"I Don't Know How To Love Him"

(3, 5).clue: A small liquid measure equivalent to 1/60 of a dram

(4, 5).clue: Lonely Planet says this city 15 miles from the equator is the only world capital threatened by an active volcano

(5, 5).clue: From the French for "evening", this word for a party can also be followed by "dansante"

(6, 5).clue: This former Maine senator helped broker a peace deal in Northern Ireland

(1, 1).clue: In "On His Blindness", John Milton wrote, "they also serve who only stand and" do this

(2, 1).clue: This sleep stage during which most dreams occur was discovered in 1953

(3, 1).clue: In "Mulan", Mushu is one of these legendary creatures

(4, 1).clue: It's about a 30-minute walk from the Rembrandt House Museum to the Amsterdam museum named for this artist

(5, 1).clue: Don't miss the truck-mounted giant potato at the spud drive-in in this state's town of Driggs

(6, 1).clue: A handmade object, like a shard of pottery, found at an archaeological dig

(1, 2).clue: This lake poet's "Ecclesiastical Sonnets" is a history of the church in England

(2, 2).clue: Sadly, in 2003 it was goodbye to this cloned sheep who was put to sleep due to a lung disease

(3, 2).clue: Angus in "Brave" is Merida's horse, of course, one of these big ones

(4, 2).clue: This Fauvist designed Vence's Rosaire Chapel, down to its vestments & stained-glass windows

(5, 2).clue: This 320'-wide Howard Hughes creation from 1947 today nests at Oregon's Evergreen Aviation & Space Museum

(6, 2).clue: To render void, as a contract

(1, 3).clue: Some of this Maine-born poet's finest verse appears in her 1931 collection "Fatal Interview", a group of love sonnets

(2, 3).clue: Named for a Shakespearean couple, these 2 large moons of Uranus were discovered in 1787

(3, 3).clue: This sidekick of Captain Hook wishes to return to a simpler life of "scuttling ships... cutting throats"

(4, 3).clue: This Leonardo drawing of a man inside a circle & a square is named after a Roman architect

(5, 3).clue: John Milkovisch made the aluminum siding at his Houston home from 50,000 of these former cold ones

(6, 3).clue: White port is usually served as an aperitif, though most port is drunk as this opposite

(1, 4).clue: This sonnet form is named for the 14th century poet who perfected it

(2, 4).clue: In 1576 King Frederick II granted him title to the island of Ven to build an observatory

(3, 4).clue: In "Diamonds Are Forever", 007 was attacked by a bikini-clad woman who shared a name with this 1942 Disney sidekick

(4, 4).clue: His 1911 work "I and the Village" evokes the look of his Hasidic hometown

(5, 4).clue: Seen in many sci-fi movies, the VLA, this system, listens in from Socorro, New Mexico

(6, 4).clue: It's the portmanteau word for the piece of furniture that has both drawers & hanging space for clothes

(1, 5).clue: In 1922, 4 years before his death, this German-language poet produced the 55 "Sonnets to Orpheus"

(2, 5).clue: In 1643 this Italian inverted a 4-foot mercury-filled tube in a dish, creating the first barometer

(3, 5).clue: The song heard before the credits as fireworks explode over the castle was sung originally by this sidekick

(4, 5).clue: Female impressionists included Mary Cassatt and this femme, Manet's sister-in-law

(5, 5).clue: The Lake Whitefish is often found in this lake where a 43-pounder was caught in 1918

(6, 5).clue: At 16,067 feet above sea level, it's the highest mountain in Antarctica

(0, 0).clue: Twice as long as Hadrian's Wall, Offa's Dyke was the traditional border between these 2 lands
